author: By Chris Cameron
title: Peter Meijer, a Republican Who Voted to Impeach Trump, Is Running for Senate
description: The one-term representative of Michigan who was defeated by a Trump-backed primary challenger is aiming for a political comeback.
content: Peter Meijer, the one-term Republican congressman who lost his seat after voting to impeach President Donald J. Trump, has announced he is running for Senate in Michigan, jumping into a crowded primary in a key battleground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: The Heart of ‘Priscilla’ Is for Sale
description: Is there such a thing as cool movie merch? The film studio A24 makes a case for it — now with a $400 necklace based on Sofia Coppola’s “Priscilla.”
content: It is curious how some things never go out of style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen and Natalija Gormalova
title: Ending TB Is Within Reach — So Why Are Millions Still Dying?
description: Tuberculosis has passed Covid as the top infectious disease killer, despite new medicines and better diagnostic tools.
content: At Kaneshie Polyclinic, a health center in a hardscrabble neighborhood of Accra, the capital of Ghana, there is a rule. Every patient who walks through the door — a woman in labor, a construction worker with an injury, a child with malaria — is screened for tuberculosis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Man Whose Son Is Accused of Parade Shooting Pleads Guilty to Misdemeanors
description: Robert Crimo Jr., whose son is accused in a shooting at a Fourth of July parade in 2022, agreed to a plea that will send him to jail for 60 days.
content: Robert Crimo Jr. knew that his young son had threatened violence in the family home, promising to “kill everyone,” prosecutors said. The son, Robert Crimo III, had expressed interest in committing a mass shooting in an exchange with a camp counselor and later sent text messages suggesting that he wanted to end his own life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: It Is Not Dead Yet! ‘Spamalot’ Returns to Broadway. (Cue the Coconuts.)
description: The Monty Python-inspired show wants to give audiences a reason “to laugh and enjoy and be taken away by this lunacy, in the best way possible.”
content: The terrifying knights still say “Ni!” The dead? Well, they are not quite dead yet. And King Arthur and his Knights of the Round Table (not dawn, not dusk, not late afternoon, but knights) still trot around to the sounds of coconuts banging together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Baker
title: The Statue of Liberty Is the Setting for an Israel-Hamas War Protest
description: Protests over the war have been organized almost daily across the United States.
content: Hundreds of protesters boarded ferries to the Statue of Liberty on Monday, carrying banners calling for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war that they unfurled from the statue’s pedestal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ameera Harouda, Maria Abi-Habib and Abu Bakr Bashir
title: As Gaza Hospitals Collapse, Medical Workers Face the Hardest Choices
description: Doctors say they are performing surgeries without anesthesia after weeks of Israeli bombings and siege left severe shortages of medicine, water, food and fuel. “We choose who gets ventilation by deciding who has the best chance of survival,” one doctor said.
content: Every day is a choice between who lives and who dies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Atul Loke
title: Cricket Gives a Nation Bowed by Violence a Reason to Stand Tall
description: Afghanistan’s cricket team has won big games and many fans in an international competition, in a stark contrast to the pariah status of its government.
content: The national flag they play under no longer exists officially. The anthem they stand for at the beginning of every game belongs to a republic that was toppled two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John J. Lennon
title: Can the Parole Process Make Prison Sentences More Just?
description: In “Correction,” Ben Austen investigates a system meant to promote rehabilitation, and reward prisoners who change, but that no longer seems to work the way it was intended.
content: One morning in late September, around the time I was finishing Ben Austen’s “Correction: Parole, Prison, and the Possibility of Change,” I was walking the perimeter of a prison yard in upstate New York with a fellow inmate, 68-year-old Kasiem Chaves. We call him “Old God.” Gray and gangly, he was about to go before the parole board for the third time, having served nearly 41 years. By the time I finished writing this review, I would know whether Old God would go free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: In Queens, Strangers Become Neighbors
description: Rent increases in a building in Sunnyside encouraged tenants to band together. Now they know one another’s names and help keep an eye on building management.
content: It wasn’t a dramatic rent increase. “Just $35.01,” said Sam Ida, who received a letter informing him of the change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Whitney Wolfe Herd Is Stepping Down as Bumble’s C.E.O. After a Decade
description: Ms. Wolfe Herd, who founded the women-centered dating app in 2014, will be replaced by Lidiane Jones, the chief executive of Slack.
content: Whitney Wolfe Herd, who founded the women-centered dating app Bumble a decade ago, is stepping down and will be replaced by Lidiane Jones, the chief executive of the workplace-messaging platform Slack, Bumble said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Trump May Not Need a Coup This Time
description: The new Times/Siena poll is to Biden’s second-term ambitions what sunlight is to morning fog.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, I know you’re busy writing about your reporting trip to Israel, and I am looking forward to reading all your thoughts. But, gee, can we talk about the Times/Siena poll on the presidential race that came out on Sunday? Donald Trump is ahead in almost all the critical states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh and Pete Kiehart
title: Before Sunrise, Before the Runners, a Guerrilla Bike Marathon
description: For the last two decades, cyclists have been riding the course in the magic time after the roads are closed and before the thousands of racers begin.
content: It was well before dawn on Sunday when the cyclists first began to congregate — a handful at first, then a few dozen, then hundreds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Israel’s ‘Large Attack’ on Gaza, and More
description: Plus, Trump faces questioning in his fraud trial and a Times poll finds Biden trailing in swing states.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Democrats in Congress Weigh Calls for Cease-Fire Amid Pressure From the Left
description: They have grown more vocal about urging measures to mitigate civilian casualties in Gaza, but supporters of a cease-fire are few and far between.
content: Democrats in Congress, torn between their support for Israel in its war with Hamas and concern about civilian suffering in Gaza, are struggling with how far to go in calling for measures to mitigate civilian casualties as the left wing of the party escalates pressure for a cease-fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Fighting a Cold, Pope Francis Hands Out a Speech Instead of Reading It
description: The pope, 86, who has had a number of medical scares in recent years, met Monday with European rabbis. The Vatican stressed his illness was nothing serious.
content: Pope Francis delivered written instead of verbal remarks on Monday in a meeting with a delegation of European rabbis because he has a slight cold, according to the Vatican.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Is Lending Billions to Countries in Financial Trouble
description: Instead of lending money for highways and bridges, China has shifted to providing emergency rescues for previous borrowers.
content: After lending $1.3 trillion to developing countries, mainly for big-ticket infrastructure projects, China has shifted its focus to bailing out many of those same countries from piles of debt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: A Judge Tries to Do What Few Have Accomplished: Rein in Trump
description: Through the first few hours of Donald J. Trump’s time on the witness stand, he and Judge Arthur F. Engoron traded irritated facial expressions.
content: On the first day of Donald J. Trump’s testimony in Manhattan, the judge presiding over the civil fraud case against the former president tried to do what Hillary Clinton, a star-studded lineup of debate moderators and even Mr. Trump’s own lawyers could not: make Mr. Trump stop talking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Filipino Radio Journalist Fatally Shot During Live Broadcast
description: A gunman shot and killed Juan Jumalon, known to his followers as D.J. Johnny Walker, while he was livestreaming his radio show on Facebook.
content: A Filipino radio journalist, Juan Jumalon, was shot and killed during a live broadcast at his home in the southwest Philippines early on Sunday, according to the local authorities, who were searching for possibly multiple attackers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.5 Million Homes in California
description: A midcentury-modern house in Claremont, a three-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1937 home in Glendale.
content: This house won a 1964 design award sponsored by a trade group to promote the use of concrete in residential building. It was designed by Fred McDowell, an architect who worked extensively in Southern California in the mid-20th century and was responsible for a number of buildings at nearby Pitzer College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Anne Brown
title: Male-Killing Virus Is Discovered in Insects
description: The chance finding in a Japanese university’s greenhouse could help researchers find ways to control agricultural pests or even insects that spread disease.
content: Scientists in Japan have identified a virus that selectively kills males — and it happens to be inheritable, creating generation upon generation of all females.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel Horti
title: The Novel Source for This Space Mystery? A Novel.
description: Video games rarely adapt books. But with The Invincible, a Polish studio embraces a science fiction story by Stanislaw Lem.
content: Humanity’s first contact with tiny quasi-intelligent robots felt fresh and believable to the video game producer Marek Markuszewski as he devoured “The Invincible,” Stanislaw Lem’s 1964 science fiction novel, in two evenings. Its precise descriptions of force fields and antimatter cannons seemed ready-made for the screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Ruth Igielnik and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Indictments Haven’t Sunk His Campaign, but a Conviction Might
description: Polls by The New York Times and Siena College show his strength in key swing states, in part because of concerns about President Biden’s age. But a conviction could be the difference in 2024.
content: For Donald J. Trump, a new set of New York Times/Siena College polls captures a stunning, seemingly contradictory picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Zdenek Macal, Conductor With an International Reach, Dies at 87
description: Shuttling between Europe and the United States, he conducted the world’s great orchestras. He was music director of the New Jersey Symphony for 11 years.
content: Zdenek Macal, a Czech-born conductor who drew a distinctively rich and full sound from orchestras in several countries, including the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, where his tenure is regarded by musicians and administrators as something of a golden age, died on Oct. 25 in Prague. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: Jordan Airdrops Medical Aid to Its Field Hospital in Gaza
description: It appeared to be the first time in the war that aid was dropped from a plane. Israel’s siege of Gaza has put some hospitals out of service.
content: King Abdullah II of Jordan said on Monday that his country’s air force had airdropped “urgent medical aid” to a field hospital operated by the kingdom in the Gaza Strip. The Israeli military confirmed the unusual move and said in a statement that it had been a coordinated effort between the neighboring nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Review: In This ‘120 Days of Sodom,’ Sadism Stands in the Way
description: The provocations in Milo Rau’s stage adaptation, featuring actors with Down syndrome, confuse the production as it grapples with weighty issues.
content: Is anything even shocking on a stage anymore? Simulated rape, coprophilia and torture all feature heavily in Milo Rau’s “The Last Generation, or the 120 Days of Sodom,” a theater production starring actors with Down syndrome that opened Saturday at the Théâtre de Liège, in Belgium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: bafflement
description: This word has appeared in 25 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word bafflement has appeared in 25 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 24 in “Is Roz Chast ‘Terrible at Decorating’? You Decide” by Joanne Kaufman:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: When a Child Is Shot, Trauma Ripples Through Families, Study Finds
description: Gunshots are the top cause of death for children and teenagers in the U.S. Fatal or not, the wounds reverberate through communities and the health care system.
content: With each mass shooting, Americans look to one grim indicator — the number of dead — as a measure of the destructive impact. But damage left behind by gunshot wounds reverberates among survivors and families, sending mental health disorders soaring and shifting huge burdens onto the health care system, a new analysis of private health insurance claims shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Trump’s Testimony in Fraud Trial Will Not Be Televised
description: Those hoping to watch Donald J. Trump on the witness stand in his civil fraud trial had to go to the courtroom in person.
content: People wishing to watch Donald J. Trump testify in his civil fraud trial on Monday will be largely out of luck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift’s Blockbuster ‘1989’ Rerecording Tops Sales of Original
description: In a record-breaking week, the “Taylor’s Version” of the pop star’s 2014 album sold the equivalent of 1,653,000 copies in the United States.
content: Exactly nine years ago, Taylor Swift made a huge splash on the music charts with “1989,” the album that represented her full transformation into a mainstream pop star. With 1,287,000 sales in the United States, it was the biggest start for any album in more than a decade, and affirmed Swift as a megaselling force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s lawyers in the case have different approaches to representing the former president.
description: Christopher M. Kise and Alina Habba, the two lawyers who joined Donald J. Trump at the defense table before he testified Monday at his civil fraud trial in New York, represent different aspects of what the former president looks for in a defender.
content: Christopher M. Kise and Alina Habba, the two lawyers who joined Donald J. Trump at the defense table before he testified Monday at his civil fraud trial in New York, represent different aspects of what the former president looks for in a defender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By T.M. Brown
title: Food Apps Catering to Chinese Speakers Deliver a Piece of Home
description: Some mobile platforms are helping Chinese speakers in the United States and elsewhere order in their native language.
content: When Chong Zhou moved to New York City in 2013, she and her friends would organize entire days around trips to the Chinatown in Flushing, Queens, to eat, get foot massages and shop for groceries. Ms. Zhou, a business analyst at Meta, arrived in the United States from Shenzhen, China, in 2009 to attend Ohio State University. She had struggled to satiate her culinary homesickness in Columbus, but New York was a revelation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Poland’s Art World Awaits a Culture War Counteroffensive
description: The Law and Justice party tried to reshape the country via the arts. Now that it appears set to lose office, its critics are split over how to move on.
content: Just weeks after becoming Poland’s culture minister, in 2015, Piotr Glinski began a yearslong effort to shift his country’s cultural life toward the political right.
source.name: The New York Times

title: With Poll Results Favoring Trump, Should Biden Step Aside?
description: Readers discuss a poll showing the president behind his predecessor in five battleground states. Also: I.R.S. funding; health insurance, simplified.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim, William K. Rashbaum and Susanne Craig
title: The Trumps’ Seven Springs estate has carried very different values over the years.
description: The former president purchased the 212-acre estate in Westchester County, N.Y., in the mid-1990s with the hope of developing a golf course or luxury homes, but locals blocked his plans.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump testified on Monday that he had lowered the value of one of his properties — the sprawling Seven Springs estate in New York City’s northern suburbs — because he “thought it was too high.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: In This Country, Most People Rent for Life. Is That Really What They Want?
description: At a time when many young people in places like California and New York can’t see a path to buying a home, Switzerland offers a glimpse of a post-ownership society.
content: In any other country, Philip Skiba, a well-paid analyst working in the finance industry, might not hesitate to buy a home. But in the town where he lives, on the outskirts of Zurich, even the ugly houses, as he describes them, go for millions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson Lichtenstein
title: For Stephanie Land, College Was the School of Hard Knocks
description: In her second memoir, the author of “Maid” recounts the struggle of getting educated in America below the poverty line.
content: The last time we encountered Stephanie Land, the author of the best-selling “Maid,” she was a single mother who cleaned houses in the Pacific Northwest to get away from an abusive boyfriend, stay out of a homeless shelter and sustain a seemingly far-fetched dream of one day returning to college to become a writer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Boy George Will Join ‘Moulin Rouge!’ on Broadway in 2024
description: The British pop star will take over the role of the club owner Harold Zidler from Feb. 6 to May 12.
content: The British pop star Boy George will play the role of the enthusiastic club owner Harold Zidler in “Moulin Rouge! The Musical” next year, returning to Broadway for the first time in two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: The Annual CMA Awards and ‘The Curse’
description: The country music show airs for the 57th year. Showtime airs a new show with Nathan Fielder and Emma Stone.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 6-Nov. 12. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Oleksandr Naselenko and Emile Ducke
title: Ukraine’s Secret Plan to Save a City Trapped in Purgatory
description: Since Russian troops were pushed out of the city of Kherson, they have bombed it relentlessly. Closely held river operations could change that.
content: It was just after 1 p.m. when the first of three artillery shells shrieked past Maryna Korifadze’s bomb shelter in Kherson, landing nearby with a bone-rattling crump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Arizona, New Shot at Finding the Truth About Love
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 6, 2023.
content: “I’m so happy to have a schedule again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: More Semiconductors, Less Housing: China’s New Economic Plan
description: Policymakers, wary of inciting reckless borrowing in real estate, are instead investing heavily in factories and trying to help indebted local governments.
content: China’s political leaders, under pressure to support the country’s fragile recovery, are slowly steering the economy on a new course. No longer able to rely on real estate and local debt to drive growth, they are instead investing more heavily in manufacturing and increasing borrowing by the central government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: The Easiest Chicken Noodle Soup for the Busiest Season
description: Alexa Weibel’s clever recipe gets maximal flavor out of minimal ingredients.
content: A nasty bug took up residence in our house recently, felling us all for a miserable few days. Boy were we grateful for the miracle nutrition of Alexa Weibel’s easiest chicken noodle soup!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Investigators Head to Antarctica Research Base After Claims of Sexual Violence
description: The National Science Foundation watchdog is sending agents to a U.S. research base in Antarctica after a 2022 report raised concerns about sexual misconduct.
content: The independent monitor for the National Science Foundation is sending investigators to McMurdo Station in Antarctica who should arrive on Monday after a report last year raised concerns about sexual assault and harassment at a U.S. research base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Vapes Get a Gen Z Makeover
description: In candy shades and eggy shapes, many of today’s most popular vaping devices look like toys. Experts worry they will hook a new generation of users.
content: Alexa Addison remembers what vapes looked like when she was in high school. The dominant e-cigarette was Juul, a slim, black rectangle with sharp corners that resembled a flash drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: U.N. Says Israel-Gaza War Is Deadliest Ever for Its Personnel
description: The U.N. secretary general, António Guterres, said Monday that 89 employees of UNRWA, its agency aiding Palestinian refugees, had been killed since the war began.
content: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, said on Monday that 89 employees of the U.N. agency aiding Palestinian refugees, known as UNRWA, had been killed in Gaza in the month of war between Israel and Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Nov. 6, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 6, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Ben Protess
title: Trump Assails Judge and Concedes a Role in Valuing His Empire’s Property
description: The former president, who also railed against New York’s attorney general in front of a packed courtroom, denied he committed fraud and called the trial “very unfair.”
content: He was belligerent and brash, unrepentant and verbose — regardless of the courtroom setting, he was the quintessential Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration, After Setbacks, Talks Up Renewable Power Gains
description: The administration said 15 clean energy projects were making solid progress and that it was on track to meet its goals for 2025.
content: The Biden administration announced on Monday progress on 15 large renewable energy projects, an apparent effort to project confidence in an industry that is facing steep challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Five Wounded as Russian Missiles Strike Odesa, Damaging an Art Museum
description: In another setback, Ukraine said 19 soldiers had been killed in a strike on a medals ceremony last week. Unusually, the ceremony had been held in the open, rather than a protected space.
content: A day after Ukraine damaged a Russian naval vessel in an airstrike on Crimea, Russia hit the southern Ukrainian city of Odesa with missiles and drones, injuring five people and damaging an art museum founded in the 19th century, local and military authorities said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fiona Maazel
title: Paul Auster Walks the Long Valley of Grief in a New Novel
description: In “Baumgartner,” a professor contends with mortality and the haunting memory of his wife.
content: I can hear the whingeing already: Nothing happens in this novel. It’s too slow, it’s boring, it’s not high concept or high event. And in a nod to how conditioned we — or at least I — have become to expect high event, I spent the first 25 pages of “Baumgartner” waiting for its namesake to be kidnapped, maimed or just locked in a closet by the meter man. When it was clear this just wasn’t going to be that kind of novel, I had to start over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: The Israeli military announced that its forces had fully encircled Gaza City and were carrying out “a significant operation” in the Gaza Strip late yesterday, as the entire enclave was plunged into the same kind of widespread communications blackout that cut it off from the world during Israel’s initial ground invasion 10 days ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: The State Department Approves $320 Million Sale of Guided Bomb Equipment to Israel
description: Israel has been using the kits during its bombing campaign in Gaza.
content: The U.S. State Department has approved a $320 million sale to Israel of equipment for kits that turn unguided bombs into more precise, GPS-guided munitions, according to a letter sent by the department to Congress that was obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton and Erin Schaff
title: Tech Start-Ups Try to Sell a Cautious Pentagon on A.I.
description: Shield AI, a tech start-up, already has a drone run by artificial intelligence being used by the Israeli military. But persuading the Pentagon to embrace the technology remains a big challenge.
content: When he reflected on his time as a Navy SEAL serving in Afghanistan a decade ago, Brandon Tseng wondered why he and his team did not have any way to see inside buildings they were about to raid and reduce the chances of walking into a deadly trap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Report of Hit-and-Run at Stanford Prompts Hate Crime Inquiry
description: The authorities opened the inquiry after an Arab Muslim student said that a driver struck him with an S.U.V. as he walked on campus.
content: The authorities have opened a hate crime investigation into the report of a hit-and-run on Friday that left an Arab Muslim student injured at Stanford University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Wehner
title: Republicans Have Chosen Nihilism
description: Conservatives have to find a way to turn back toward their original ideals.
content: Over the past half-century, one of the books that most electrified conservatives was Allan Bloom’s “The Closing of the American Mind.” Bloom, a political philosopher, warned of the dangers posed by moral relativism and nihilism, of “accepting everything and denying reason’s power.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg and Adam Entous
title: Blinken Warns Iran Against Widening the Conflict Between Israel and Hamas
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken warned Iran during a weekend of diplomacy in the Middle East. The U.S. military posted a photo of one of its submarines in the region.
content: If Iran had any doubts about American resolve in the Middle East, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, with an assist from the Pentagon, spent the weekend reinforcing the notion that the United States was not going anywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Assail Trump’s Bid to Have Federal Election Case Dismissed
description: Prosecutors said that Mr. Trump’s barrage of motions to have the case tossed out were full of “distortions and misrepresentations.”
content: Federal prosecutors on Monday asked a judge to reject a barrage of motions filed last month by former President Donald J. Trump that sought to toss out the indictment charging him with plotting to overturn the 2020 election and said his claims were full of “distortions and misrepresentations.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Inside the Courtroom at Trump’s Fraud Trial
description: Here’s a closer look at the scene through a photograph taken Monday just before former President Donald J. Trump took the stand.
content: Donald J. Trump began his testimony Monday before a packed Manhattan courtroom, filled with onlookers. They had come to witness the spectacle of a former U.S. president taking the witness stand at trial to defend his family business and his reputation as a real estate mogul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Mooj Zadie, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Luke Vander Ploeg, Marc Georges, Rachel Quester, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Alyssa Moxley
title: Swing State Voters Are Souring on Biden
description: A new Times/Siena poll finds Donald Trump leading President Biden in five of six key battlegrounds.
content: In a major new campaign poll from The New York Times and Siena College, former President Donald J. Trump leads President Biden in five of the six battleground states likeliest to decide the 2024 presidential race. Widespread discontent with the state of the country and growing doubts about Biden’s ability to perform his job as president threaten to unravel the diverse coalition that elected him in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Adam Sella
title: Called to Serve, Israeli Reservists Wait to Deploy
description: Facing a military campaign with no end in sight, tens of thousands of soldiers in Israel find themselves in a holding pattern.
content: For the 360,000 reservists who have been called up as Israel goes to war in Gaza, there are plenty of ways to conjure up nightmares: taking part in a combat operation that accidentally kills an Israeli hostage held by Hamas, confronting Hamas fighters as they pop up from tunnels in a chaotic urban landscape or simply coming upon a Palestinian child who strays within rifle range.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Tuesday Briefing: Israel Cuts the Gaza Strip in Two
description: Plus, Trump testifies at his civil fraud trial.
content: Israel’s military said yesterday that it had encircled Gaza City, effectively splitting the Gaza Strip in half. Israel said the move would make it harder for Hamas to retain control of the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: What to Know About Trump’s Civil Fraud Trial
description: The former president will testify Monday in a Manhattan courtroom as he tries to preserve the business empire that made his name.
content: Follow live updates on the civil fraud trial against Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Della Volpe
title: Joe Biden Is in Trouble
description: The winning 2020 Biden coalition is at risk of fracturing.
content: The savage terrorist attack on Israel and the ensuing war in Gaza are spurring many young Americans to engage with the political moment at a heightened intensity that could, ultimately, influence the 2024 presidential race. President Biden is offering fulsome support to Israel, though with more words of caution recently. Yet according to multiple recent polls, fewer than a quarter of young voters — who were crucial to Democratic victories in 2020 and overperformance in 2022 — approve of the way that the president is handling the response to the war between Israel and Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: How Democrats Lost Voters With a ‘Compensate Losers’ Strategy
description: A shift from preventing inequality in the first place to fixing it after the fact has cost the party, a paper argues.
content: A lot of Democrats are bewildered by why their party isn’t doing better in campaigns against a Republican Party that is deeply dysfunctional. A new paper by three economists proposes a fresh explanation that seems persuasive to me. It says the Democrats went astray right around … 1976.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Morton Turner
title: The U.S. Can Counter China’s Control of Minerals for the Energy Transition
description: America needs to invest in mining and build resilient supply chains for the building blocks of electric batteries.
content: China recently rattled the world’s electric vehicle supply chains by announcing new export controls on graphite, a key component of lithium-ion batteries. If China uses the export controls, which take effect on Dec. 1, to reduce exports of graphite or to favor Chinese-owned companies operating abroad, it could slow down efforts to scale up advanced battery manufacturing globally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: OpenAI Lets Mom-and-Pop Shops Customize ChatGPT
description: With a new GPTs service, anyone can build a chatbot and instantly share it with friends, family and the general public.
content: OpenAI said on Monday that it had created a service that allows individuals and small businesses to build customized versions of its popular online chatbot, ChatGPT, and instantly share them on the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William D. Cohan
title: Were These Artworks Looted? After Seizures and Lawsuits, Some Still Debate
description: Several museums and collectors have surrendered artworks by Egon Schiele to investigators who say they were looted. But others are asserting that the evidence is inconclusive.
content: For decades, several important museums and collectors ignored suggestions that the works they owned by the Austrian master Egon Schiele had been stolen by the Nazis from a Viennese cabaret performer, Fritz Grünbaum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Vogel
title: Have Art Auctions Become ‘Must-See TV’?
description: Teleprompter! Makeup! Auction houses no longer play exclusively to the art world as viewers flock to YouTube, Instagram and TikTok to see how the one percent spends.
content: As Sotheby’s and Christie’s prepare for the start this week of the  major New York auctions of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art — at which a 1932 Picasso is expected to bring in more than $120 million — teams of tech experts, producers and show directors are readying their salesrooms as if they were CNN Central.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Trump Testified at His New York Civil Fraud Trial
description: Also, Israel said it encircled Gaza City. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: During four hours of testimony in a Manhattan courtroom today, Donald Trump repeatedly attacked the judge overseeing the trial and defended himself against accusations of fraudulently misvaluing his properties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Frankies 457 Sicilian Olive Oils for Drizzling Over Everything
description: A chocolate snowflake for the holiday table, a new hot sauce from Noma and more food news.
content: Frank Falcinelli and Frank Castronovo, the owners of Frankies 457 in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, also happen to have a piece of the Asaro Family Farm, in the Belice Valley in southwest Sicily. The Franks have added some new products bearing the restaurant’s name. A basic everyday oil, sold by the liter, is a blend of Nocellara del Belice, Biancolilla and hearty Cerasuola olives, all Sicilian natives, golden, with a peppery edge in its finish ($27.99 for 1 liter). Then there’s a Calabrian Chili Oil ($21.99 for 17 ounces), ruddy, with vibrant heat from three kinds of chiles blended into the Sicilian oil; the Franks suggest drizzling it on pizza. The organic extra virgin oil made entirely from Nocellara del Belice, greener and more herbal ($34.99 for 17 ounces), has been on the market for some time and is still available. They have also introduced six traditional organic pastas made from ancient grains, cut on bronze dies and air-dried ($7.49 a pound), and deliciously meaty Castelvetrano olives and whole Sicilian black (brownish) olives, each $8.49 for 12 ounces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: Will the Supreme Court Toss Out a Gun Law Meant to Protect Women?
description: Even pro-firearms politicians are absent in the briefs supporting a lawsuit to make it harder to keep weapons out of abusers’ hands.
content: Ever since the Supreme Court agreed in June to hear the government’s appeal of a particularly noxious Second Amendment ruling, I had been curious to see which “friends of the court” might emerge on the gun-rights side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyoko Hamada and Victoria Petro-Conroy
title: This Season’s Most Striking Sculptural Bags
description: Accessories with distinctive silhouettes, from soft-sided globes to hard-edged minaudières.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Buchanan and Josh Katz
title: How 7,500 More Reader Drawings Changed Our New York City Maps
description: We’ve added 36 new neighborhood names, and we’ll continue to update them.
content: Since we published this extremely detailed map of New York City neighborhoods last week, readers have sent in more than 7,500 new submissions from across the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: How Rebecca Yarros Packed Dragons, Magic and Steamy Sex Into a Blockbuster Fantasy
description: Yarros drew on her experience with chronic illness and life in a military family to write “Fourth Wing,” a huge best seller that spawned a spicy fantasy series.
content: When Rebecca Yarros pitched her publisher a sexy fantasy about telepathic dragons and their riders, she thought it might be a tough sell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch and Kelley Manley
title: Second Police Officer Acquitted in Elijah McClain Death
description: Nathan Woodyard was the first officer to stop Mr. McClain in what became a violent encounter. The young, unarmed Black man died days later.
content: A second Colorado police officer has been acquitted in the 2019 death of Elijah McClain, a young, unarmed Black man whose case attracted national attention and became central to debates about police brutality and race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: At 50, the Kronos Quartet Is Still Playing for the Future
description: The group, which celebrated its birthday on Friday at Carnegie Hall, changed music with its open-eared and open-minded approach.
content: Late one night in 1973, a young violinist named David Harrington was listening to the radio. He heard some music that was just a few years old: George Crumb’s “Black Angels,” a harsh and eerie, prayerful and screaming piece for amplified string quartet, full of grief and anger about the quagmire in Vietnam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: Some Covid Vaccines Are Still Hard to Find
description: Vaccine appointments for kids remain limited, and Novavax shots are hard to come by.
content: The recently authorized Covid vaccines promised to protect the public against an expected uptick of respiratory illness this winter. But getting shots into arms is still proving challenging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Treasury Secretary Yellen to Hold Economic Talks With Chinese Counterpart
description: The high-level meetings in San Francisco will lay the groundwork for talks between President Biden and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen will hold two days of high-level meetings with her Chinese counterpart, Vice Premier He Lifeng, this week, as the United States and China look to build upon an effort that started this year to improve communication between the world’s two largest economies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, Jeffery C. Mays and William K. Rashbaum
title: Mayor’s 25-Year-Old Fund-Raising Chief in Spotlight After F.B.I. Raid
description: A recent college graduate, Brianna Suggs was an unusual choice to run Eric Adams’s big-money fund-raising operation as he campaigned for mayor.
content: The choice was unconventional: Eric Adams, the candidate who would go on to win the 2021 election for mayor of the nation’s financial capital, had picked an inexperienced 23-year-old to run his campaign’s fund-raising operation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: Young Men Seek Answers to an Age-Old Question: How to Be Hot
description: “Looksmaxxers” are a booming online community creating new terms for age-old insecurities.
content: Skin-care routines, hair care, a good night’s sleep: These are not cutting-edge suggestions for how to look one’s best, at least not for anyone who has ever consulted a women’s magazine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Antisemitic and Islamophobic Incidents Surge in Australia
description: Tensions between religious groups in Australia have risen since the start of the Israel-Hamas war.
content: Posters plastered across Sydney portraying Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel as Adolf Hitler in disguise. A record increase in reports of Islamophobia, including threats to Muslim community organizations. Antisemitic chants at a pro-Palestinian rally and charges that Nazi salutes were performed outside a Jewish museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Arrests Motivated by Politics Face a Supreme Court Test
description: A 72-year-old city councilwoman in Texas, accused of misplacing a document, says she was the victim of retaliation for exercising her First Amendment rights.
content: In her memoir, Justice Sonia Sotomayor confessed that she does not always observe the letter of the law. “I’m a New Yorker,” she wrote, “and I jaywalk with the best of them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Halperin
title: The Man Behind 250 Masks
description: Inside the sizable collection amassed by the artist Marcel Dzama, whose work plays with disguise.
content: The collection: Handmade masks, in materials ranging from paper to wood to cloth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: The Biden campaign was hardly shocked by the Times/Siena polling.
description: The campaign has circulated talking points that downplay the relevance of polling, suggest voters are not tuned in right now and offer a reminder that past presidents have recovered from low points.
content: The sour numbers for President Biden in the new polls of battleground states from The New York Times and Siena College did not come as a surprise to officials in his re-election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: City to Dismiss Citations Issued to Reporter for Asking Too Many Questions
description: A reporter for The Daily Southtown received three citations from the government of Calumet City, Ill., but the city said that it would dismiss them after hearing from the media company’s lawyer.
content: Officials in a Chicago suburb on Monday said that their city would dismiss citations that it had issued to a local news reporter in late October after he persistently contacted elected officials about a flooding issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: What Can Biden Do?
description: The president’s strategic options for 2024.
content: With President Biden having fallen behind Donald Trump in the early 2024 polls, Trump’s strategy seems fairly straightforward: more of the same. Trump will portray Biden as old, inflation as high, immigration as out of control and the nation as weak. All these arguments play into the concerns of many voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court’s Devotion to Gun Rights Faces a Challenging Test
description: The justices will hear arguments on Tuesday on whether the government can disarm people subject to restraining orders for domestic abuse.
content: The big gun rights case the Supreme Court is set to hear on Tuesday presents the justices with a tricky problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Father of Accused Gunman Goes on Trial in Illinois Parade Shooting
description: The prosecution of a Fourth of July attack that killed seven in 2022 could broaden the legal interpretation of who bears responsibility for a mass shooting.
content: In a case that could broaden the legal interpretation of who bears responsibility for a mass shooting, the father of the man accused of killing seven people at a Fourth of July parade in suburban Chicago will stand trial on Monday for reckless conduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: The Times/Siena Poll Isn’t the Only One Indicating an Unhappy Electorate
description: Three polls offered warning signs for President Biden.
content: With the 2024 election one year away, The New York Times/Siena College polls released Sunday combined with surveys from two other organizations showed a consistent picture: a deeply unhappy electorate dissatisfied with both of its main options and offering warning signs for President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Havrilesky
title: Matthew Perry Told the Truth About Everything
description: Few people can relate to a life of fame and excess like Matthew Perry’s. But many of us can recognize a struggle with shame.
content: Toward the end of Matthew Perry’s autobiography, he wrote about an encounter in which his mother told him she was proud of him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Rosenbloom
title: All the Trimmings, None of the Work: Thanksgiving in a Hotel
description: Turkey trots, holiday-themed spa treatments and multicourse feasts for those who don’t want to lift a finger: Here are five places to spend the holiday.
content: Thanksgiving is just a few weeks away, and while many Americans will be staying at home or with family and friends, others will be checking into hotels where guests can participate in turkey trots and try Thanksgiving-themed spa treatments — all while letting someone else worry about cooking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: After Two Years in Solitude, ‘Britain’s Loneliest Sheep’ Finds a Home
description: Fiona was rescued from the bottom of a Scottish cliff on Saturday and was brought to a farm, though some animal rights activists are concerned about her new home.
content: Fiona, a now-famous and once-lonely British sheep, is at the center of a social media frenzy as well as a local dispute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Could a Prominent Democrat Really Challenge Biden? It’s Unlikely, at This Point.
description: Worried Democrats have thrown out the names of popular governors and senators as possible alternatives to the president. But such a challenge appears improbable for a host of reasons.
content: Forty-four years ago tomorrow, the last serious primary opponent to a sitting Democratic president announced his campaign before 5,000 supporters in Boston.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Entous
title: Blinken Meets With Palestinian and Iraqi Leaders in Bid to Contain Gaza War
description: The U.S. secretary of state made two unannounced visits on Sunday, the first to the Israeli-occupied West Bank and the second to Baghdad.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, in visits to both the West Bank and Iraq, sought to reassure Palestinian leaders on Sunday that the United States was committed to minimizing harm to civilians under fire in the Gaza Strip from Israel and to warn Iran not to jump into the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Mark Walker
title: Biden Announces New Investments in Passenger Rail Projects
description: President Biden, a longtime Amtrak rider, exhibited a business-as-usual approach in announcing $16.4 billion in awards for rail projects, despite polls showing him trailing Donald Trump.
content: President Biden, perhaps Amtrak’s most famous advocate, announced $16.4 billion in funding for rail projects on Monday, exhibiting a business-as-usual approach as polls show him trailing former President Donald J. Trump one year before Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: In ‘Food,’ Geoff Sobelle Explores the Extremes of Eating
description: “I don’t want to tell people what to think,” the performance artist said of his latest show. “I just hope it tickles them and their curiosity.”
content: It was a little before 6:30 on a recent weeknight, and the kitchen in Geoff Sobelle’s West Village home was in chaos. Two toddlers zoomed around on a ride-on truck and begged him to read from an “Alice in Wonderland” pop-up book. “In a minute,” Sobelle told his son as he stirred artichokes that were simmering on the stove. All the while, he talked to a reporter about his solo show, “Food,” which is running as part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave festival through Nov. 18.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Gimein
title: Ever Had a Horrible Boss? ‘The Fund’ Is the Perfect Rage-Read.
description: In Rob Copeland’s “The Fund,” we learn about the notorious hedge-fund giant Ray Dalio — and the manipulative professional hellscape over which he has presided.
content: Ray Dalio is the titan behind the world’s biggest hedge fund — a deep thinker and confidant of some of Earth’s most powerful people. Now 74, he has worked diligently over the past few years to publicize his “Principles,” perhaps in the hope that his name will live on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Four Men Charged in the Case of the Missing Golden Toilet
description: The fully functioning 18-karat gold toilet, an artwork estimated to be worth $5.9 million, was stolen in 2019 from an exhibition at a stately British home.
content: Four years ago, a fully functioning 18-karat gold toilet was stolen from an art exhibition at Blenheim Palace, the birthplace of Winston Churchill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Republicans Are Hammering Democrats on the Migrant Crisis. Will It Work?
description: A pair of races in New York could have national resonance as Republicans seek to use the migrant crisis as a political cudgel against Democrats.
content: The county executive’s message was unequivocal: Erie County had an obligation to open its arms to the crush of migrants overwhelming New York City about 300 miles away. He called those who refused to help “morally repugnant.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Chatbots May ‘Hallucinate’ More Often Than Many Realize
description: When summarizing facts, ChatGPT technology makes things up about 3 percent of the time, according to research from a new start-up. A Google system’s rate was 27 percent.
content: When the San Francisco start-up OpenAI unveiled its ChatGPT online chatbot late last year, millions were wowed by the humanlike way it answered questions, wrote poetry and discussed almost any topic. But most people were slow to realize that this new kind of chatbot often makes things up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bobbi Dempsey
title: A Knock at the Door
description: A child looks on as sheriff’s deputies take inventory of her home.
content: “We don’t like having to do this, believe me,” the uniformed man at the door said in a tone that implied he had no strong feelings about it one way or the other. “We’ll try to get it over with quick.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
title: How Do You Use Checks? And Do They Work Well for You?
description: Banks are worried about check fraud and are trying to discourage the use of paper checks. But nevertheless, they persist.
content: Fewer people are writing paper checks these days, and for banks that’s a good thing. With check fraud on the rise, banks prefer other forms of payment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Why Don’t Women’s Clothes Have More Pockets?
description: A reader wonders why pockets in women’s wear remain “small and useless” — when they’re included at all. The answer is tangled up with a host of social issues, our critic writes.
content: The pocket problem is a perennial one, for good reason. The story of those — often, as you say, tiny — compartments is crammed to the brim with plot twists that involve sexism, racism, control, economic disparity and more. Who knew so many hot-button social issues could be contained in such a tiny space?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Vivienne Walt
title: Voters Aren’t Believing in Bidenomics
description: A new Times/Sienna poll shows the president behind in five of six key states. Voters cite his economic track record, indicators notwithstanding.
content: There was little good news for President Biden in the latest Times/Siena poll of 2024 battlegrounds, which found him trailing Donald Trump in five of six key states one year before voters head to the polls. (That’s despite Trump being nearly as unpopular and fighting multiple legal battles; he is taking the stand on Monday in one of them. And, on PredictIt, which is watched by political experts, Biden holds a six-point lead on Trump.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: A Democratic Governor in Mississippi? He Thinks It’s Possible.
description: With a promise to expand Medicaid and a focus on turning out Black voters, Brandon Presley is confident he can do what no Democrat has done in 20 years.
content: After stopping by a meet-and-greet in Ridgeland, a porch festival in Vicksburg, the Great Delta Bear Affair in Rolling Fork and an event on a baseball diamond in Yazoo City, Brandon Presley entered a packed room in McComb, launching into the message he believes can get a Democrat — namely, himself — elected governor of Mississippi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Cody Dorman, Who Forged a Close Bond With a Top Racehorse, Dies at 17
description: A boy with a rare genetic disorder inspired the name of the horse Cody’s Wish, who won at the Breeders’ Cup on Saturday.
content: Cody Dorman, who inspired the name of the racehorse Cody’s Wish, died Sunday, a day after the horse won at the Breeders’ Cup. He was 17.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell
title: Warring Billionaires, a Rogue Employee, a Divorce: One Hedge Fund’s Tale of Woe
description: Two Sigma, the $60 billion quantitative trading firm, has been beset by troubles this year that have tarnished its image and could hurt its future.
content: Two Sigma, one of the world’s largest hedge funds, has long prided itself on two things: the sophisticated, in-house algorithms that power its trading, and its commitment to secrecy. But recent internal troubles have forced Two Sigma to air its dirty laundry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Texas Man at Center of Supreme Court Case Says He No Longer Wants Guns
description: Zackey Rahimi has vowed “to stay away from all firearms and weapons” in a case that could expand gun rights protections, but advocates say he is not an ideal poster boy for the Second Amendment.
content: In a handwritten letter from jail, the man at the center of a major Supreme Court gun rights case to be heard on Tuesday apologized for going down “a wrong path” and wrote that he would no longer carry a gun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Would You Take Mental Health Advice From TikTok?
description: What, if anything, would make you trust the creator who shared it?
content: Think about the advice you have seen on TikTok or other social media platforms. How often do you find these tips — whether they are about health, relationships, skin care, fashion, fitness or anything else — helpful? How often do you question if they are based on fact? How much do you care about whether the people creating the content identify as experts, or at least have a background in what they’re talking about?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Cassandra Vinograd
title: Imprisoned Nobel Winner and Iranian Rights Activist Begins a Hunger Strike
description: Narges Mohammadi is protesting the prison’s denial of hospital treatment for her heart condition, her family said.
content: Narges Mohammadi, the imprisoned Iranian human rights activist who won this year’s Nobel Peace Prize, began a hunger strike on Monday, after she was denied hospital treatment for two blocked coronary arteries, her family said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: At Paul Taylor, a Drum Circle and a Fierce Sisterhood
description: A new work by Larry Keigwin and a company premiere by Ulysses Dove join programs that benefit from live music.
content: When designing sets for the choreographer Paul Taylor, the artist Alex Katz had a habit he called “killing the center.” Katz would stick obstacles in the middle of the stage — fake boulders, a bunch of mirrors, cutouts of dogs — to deny Taylor the easy power of that theatrical focal point. Taylor always rose to the creative challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Behind the Gates of a Private World for Only the Wealthiest New Yorkers
description: Although everyday life has become increasingly unaffordable for almost everyone, a new class of private, members-only and concierge services is emerging.
content: It’s a great time to be rich in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Udel
title: What I Read to My Son When the World Is on Fire
description: Children’s literature, in its simplicity, brevity and empathy, can make it a singularly effective way to understand the chaos of the world.
content: Last May, my husband and I invited a Palestinian friend for Shabbat dinner, and when he asked what to bring, I requested a book about his homeland for our 7-year-old son. Because this friend is lavishly generous and wasn’t sure of our child’s reading level, he showed up with a gift bag of titles about Palestinian children and their experiences, ranging from picture books to a four-volume series of middle-grade novels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: San Francisco Shop Owner Responds to Hate Crime With Message of Love
description: An ice cream shop owner was devastated by vandalism to her store, but she now sees a new way forward.
content: It’s Monday. A San Francisco shop owner is trying to turn a hate crime into a positive. Plus, what the Golden Gate Bridge is (finally) doing to prevent suicides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Elie Levine
title: How to Line Up a Great Connections Solve
description: Get tips and tricks from other solvers and the game’s editors.
content: We’ve been getting a lot of questions about how to get better at Connections, the newest game in the New York Times Games catalog. While there’s not a single best strategy, we’ve had a lot of fun over the past few months developing our own approaches. We spoke to a few experienced solvers and the game’s editors to get some tips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: What We Can Expect Donald Trump to Say in Court Today
description: When he takes the stand in his civil fraud trial, the former president is likely to testify that he was too busy to bother with the details of forms for banks.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll find out what to listen for today when Donald Trump testifies in his civil trial in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Igielnik
title: How and why we did this swing-state poll.
description: The Times/Siena College polls were conducted in six swing states that are likely to decide the 2024 election.
content: The Times/Siena College battleground polls released on Sunday and Monday were conducted over the past week in six swing states that are likely to decide the election: Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. Five of the states were won by Donald J. Trump in 2016 and then flipped by Joseph R. Biden Jr. in 2020. Nevada, which has always been a close state, came down to less than one percentage point in the 2022 U.S. Senate election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King and Lisa Lerer
title: As Black Voters Drift to Trump, Biden’s Allies Say They Have Work to Do
description: New York Times/Siena College polling painted a worrisome picture of the president’s standing with a crucial constituency. Democratic strategists warned that the erosion could threaten his re-election.
content: Black voters are more disconnected from the Democratic Party than they have been in decades, frustrated with what many see as inaction on their political priorities and unhappy with President Biden, a candidate they helped lift to the White House just three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Artificial Intelligence War Machines Take Flight
description: Far out in the prairies of North Dakota, we saw firsthand how artificial intelligence tools are being merged with military surveillance and weapons.
content: Far out in the prairies of North Dakota, we saw firsthand how artificial intelligence tools are being merged with military surveillance and weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know These Military-Themed Books That Became Movies?
description: With Veterans Day coming up, here’s short quiz that tests your knowledge on the film adaptations of books about those who served.
content: With Veterans Day coming up, here’s short quiz that tests your knowledge on the film adaptations of books about those who served.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Michael Gonchar
title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Birds, Baseball, Bankman-Fried
description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
content: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: What Each Candidate Needs to Prove on the Debate Stage
description: G.O.P. candidates onstage all need to break through a crowded field, but each faces a particular challenge.
content: G.O.P. candidates onstage all need to break through a crowded field, but each faces a particular challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis, Emma Goldberg and Ella Koeze
title: Most Americans still have to commute every day. Here’s how that experience has changed.
description: More than three years since the beginning of the pandemic, more than 100 million workers are back to commuting or never stopped. For many, their commutes have changed in ways both good and bad. Take a data-driven dive into what’s happened to the American commute.
content: More than three years since the beginning of the pandemic, more than 100 million workers are back to commuting or never stopped. For many, their commutes have changed in ways both good and bad. Take a data-driven dive into what’s happened to the American commute.
source.name: The New York Times
